column3: and the county seat of
column4: Coconino County in northern Arizona
column5: in the southwestern United States. In 2019
column6: the city's estimated population was 75
column7: 038. Flagstaff's combined metropolitan area has an estimated population of 139

column1: Flagstaff lies near the southwestern edge of the Colorado Plateau and within the San Francisco volcanic field
column2: along the western side of the largest contiguous ponderosa pine forest in the continental United States. The city sits at around 7
column3: 000 feet (2
column4: 100 m) and is next to Mount Elden
column5: just south of the San Francisco Peaks
column6: the highest mountain range in the state of Arizona. Humphreys Peak
column7: the highest point in Arizona at 12
column8: 633 feet (3
column10: is about 10 miles (16 km) north of Flagstaff in Kachina Peaks Wilderness. The geology of the Flagstaff area includes exposed rock from the Mesozoic and Paleozoic eras
column11: with Moenkopi Formation red sandstone having once been quarried in the city; many of the historic downtown buildings were constructed with it. The Rio de Flag river runs through the city.

column1: Originally settled by the pre-Columbian native Sinagua people
column2: the area of Flagstaff has fertile land from volcanic ash after eruptions in the 11th century. It was first settled as the present-day city in 1876. Local businessmen lobbied for Route 66 to pass through the city
column3: which it did
column4: turning the local industry from lumber to tourism and developing downtown Flagstaff. In 1930
column5: Pluto was discovered from Flagstaff. The city developed further through to the end of the 1960s
column6: with various observatories also used to choose Moon landing sites for the Apollo missions. Through the 1970s and 1980s
column7: downtown fell into disrepair
column8: but was revitalized with a major cultural heritage project in the 1990s.

column1: The city remains an important distribution hub for companies such as Nestlé Purina PetCare
column2: and is home to the U.S. Naval Observatory Flagstaff Station
column3: the United States Geological Survey Flagstaff Station
column4: and Northern Arizona University. Flagstaff has a strong tourism sector
column5: due to its proximity to Grand Canyon National Park
column6: Oak Creek Canyon
column7: the Arizona Snowbowl
column8: Meteor Crater
column9: and Historic Route 66.

column1: The Sinagua people were a pre-Columbian culture that occupied a large area in Arizona between circa 500 and 1425  CE. The Northern Sinagua were living in the pine forests of northern Arizona before moving into the area that is now Flagstaff  about 700 CE. The 1064 and 1066 eruptions of Sunset Crater covered the area in ash
column2: which greatly enriched the soil for farming; this also caused a population growth in the area
column3: with Ancestral Puebloans and Cohonina people also moving to the Wupatki site near the city.The Northern Sinagua had various cultural phases
column4: including Sunset Crater
column5: the Rio de Flag (leaving the Picture Canyon site)
column6: Angell and Winona
column7: Padre Canyon
column8: Elden Pueblo
column9: Turkey Hill Pueblo
column10: Clear Creek
column11: and Walnut Canyon. The Sinagua peoples left the area by the early 15th century
column12: likely moving north and later becoming the Hopi. The San Francisco Peaks
column13: which overlook Flagstaff
column14: are a sacred site in Hopi culture.Until western expansion in the 1860s
column15: the Yavapai
column16: specifically the Wi:pukba (Northeastern Yavapai)
column17: occupied the land up to the San Francisco Peaks. The Yavapai land in the area saw overlap with the land of the Northern Tonto Apache that stretched across the San Francisco Peaks to the Little Colorado River. Of the Northern Tonto Apache
column18: two tribes lived within the area of present-day Flagstaff: the Oak Creek band and the Mormon Lake band. The Mormon Lake band were centered around Flagstaff and were exclusively hunter-gatherers
column19: traveling around places like the foot of the San Francisco Peaks
column23: and Padre Canyon.The area of Flagstaff had a wagon road to California in the 1800s
column24: constructed by Edward Fitzgerald Beale's men. The first white (non-Native) settlement in the area was established by Edward Whipple
column25: who opened a saloon on the wagon road in 1871. The first permanent settlement came in 1876
column26: when Thomas F. McMillan built a cabin just north of the present-day main town. McMillan was a key developer of northern Arizona.

column2: Flagstaff began to grow
column3: and by 1886
column4: Flagstaff was the largest city on the railroad line between Albuquerque and the west coast of the United States. In 1888
column5: McMillan purchased an unfinished building that sits at the present-day intersection of Leroux Street and Route 66/Santa Fe Avenue
column6: turning it into a bank and hotel known as the Bank Hotel. Coconino County was created in 1891
column7: and Flagstaff was chosen as its county seat over nearby Williams.In 1894
column8: A. E. Douglass recommended Flagstaff to Percival Lowell as the site for the Lowell Observatory
column9: where it was built on Mars Hill. Flagstaff also became incorporated as a town in 1894. The city grew rapidly
column10: primarily due to its location along the east–west transcontinental railroad line in the United States. In the 1890s
column11: the Arizona Lumber and Timber Company was founded by the Riordan brothers to process timber. Michael and Tim Riordan worked in Flagstaff
column12: and introduced electricity to the town for this purpose. The CO Bar Ranch was opened in about 1886 by the Babbitt brothers for cattle. The Babbitt family would be very influential in northern Arizona for decades. In 1899
column13: the Northern Arizona Normal School was established; it was renamed to Northern Arizona University (NAU) in 1966.On January 1
column15: John Weatherford opened the Weatherford Hotel in Flagstaff. Weatherford opened the town's first movie theater in 1911; it collapsed under heavy snowfall a few years later
column16: but he soon replaced it with the Orpheum Theater. The Weatherford Hotel and Orpheum Theater are still in use today.

column1: The state of Arizona was admitted to the Union in 1912. Flagstaff saw its first tourism boom in the early years of the 1900s
column2: becoming known as the City of Seven Wonders
column3: as the "Seven Wonders" of the wider Flagstaff area – listed as the Coconino National Forest
column4: Grand Canyon
column5: Oak Creek Canyon
column6: San Francisco Peaks
column7: Sunset Crater
column8: Walnut Canyon
column9: and Wupatki National Monument – were more widely known.In 1926
column10: Route 66 was completed and ran through Flagstaff; the Babbitts and Riordans had staunchly supported it for the town. The railroad
column11: which became the Santa Fe Railroad
column12: had largely controlled Flagstaff until this point. The Santa Fe Railroad opened a new depot in Flagstaff in 1926
column13: to combat Route 66. As part of the celebrations
column14: Front Street was renamed Santa Fe Avenue. The people of Flagstaff collectively funded the Hotel Monte Vista
column15: which opened on January 1
column17: preparing for the next tourism boom. Flagstaff was then incorporated as a city in 1928
column23: was built at the intersection of Beaver Street and Phoenix Avenue. Flagstaff became a popular tourist stop along Route 66
column24: particularly due to its proximity to the natural wonders. In the last years of the 1920s
column25: tourism took over from traditional industries.During the Great Depression
column26: Route 66 brought unemployed workers heading to California
column28: who became unpopular as they could not afford to buy gas or food
column29: financially damaging the city by taxing its resources and not contributing to the economy. Flagstaff had also been highlighted on the map by Clyde Tombaugh's 1930 discovery of Pluto from the Lowell Observatory. However
column30: the importance of Route 66 to cross-country travel
column31: and thus to Arizona's interests on a national level
column32: did mean that it received a large share of state funding through the Depression
column33: with highway maintenance and unemployment acts providing over $1 million of funding in May 1933. In 1935
column34: many residents had enough disposable income to remodel their homes or build new ones.In 1955
column35: the United States Naval Observatory Flagstaff Station was established. Through the 1950s the city conducted the Urban Renewal Project
column36: improving housing quality in the Southside neighborhood that was largely populated by people of Spanish
column38: and Mexican heritage. Flagstaff grew and prospered through the 1960s. During the Apollo program in the 1960s
column39: the Lowell Observatory Clark Telescope was used by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) to map the Moon for the lunar expeditions
column40: enabling the mission planners to choose a safe landing site for the lunar modules.

column1: As the baby boomer generation began to start their own families in the 1970s and 1980s
column2: many moved to Flagstaff based on its small-town feel
column3: and the population began to grow again; there were not enough jobs to support the many educated individuals moving to the city. The city did not expand its infrastructure downtown despite the growing population
column4: causing problems. Several historic buildings from the 1800s were also destroyed for construction of new ones
column5: or leveled completely. Downtown Flagstaff became an uninviting place
column6: and many businesses started to move out of the area
column7: causing an economic and social decline.During the 1990s
column8: the city redeveloped. Store owners in downtown supported the Main Street programs of preservation-based revitalization
column9: and in 1992
column10: the city hired a new manager to improve the area: a different mix of shops and restaurants opened up to take advantage of the area's historical appeal. Heritage Square was built as the center of the revitalized downtown
column11: the local Flagstaff Pulliam Airport began running more flights to Phoenix
column12: allowing commuting
column13: and the school district was expanded with a third high school
column14: Sinagua High School.On October 24
column16: Flagstaff was recognized by the International Dark-Sky Association as the world's first "International Dark-Sky City".

column1: At the time of Beale's wagon road
column2: the area was known as Antelope Spring
column3: after the spring at the foot of Mars Hill (now called Antelope/Old Town Spring). The name Flagstaff comes from an actual flagstaff made from a stripped pine tree that was erected at the spring
column4: which McMillan was using as his sheep camp
column5: on July 4
column6: 1876.The common story tells that the flag-raising for which the town was named occurred when a ponderosa pine flagpole made by a scouting party from Boston (known as the "Second Boston Party") was raised to celebrate the United States Centennial. Various other stories have been told of the circumstances. One says that on July 4
column8: a surveyor for the railroad by the name of Samuel Clark Hudson
column9: accompanied by his team
column10: climbed a tall pine tree and tied a flag
column11: with another saying it was Beale's men who raised the flag in 1859. The town was still known as Antelope Spring in 1871.After the town took the name Flagstaff
column12: it began to be known as 'Old Town' for a period
column13: and was known by different names when the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad was being built through the area in 1882. It may have been known as Flagstaff Spring for a while
column14: and 'Old Town Spring' after this before simply 'Old Town'
column15: a name given after a fire destroyed much of the town
column16: with a new community then raised a few hundred yards away called 'New Town'. Another version of the Old and New Town names says that the railroad depot was moved by half a mile to prevent hill starts
column17: and business owners soon followed it
column18: displacing the commerce of the town to Front Street of 'New Town' while the houses were still in 'Old Town' with the spring; when the fire burned down 'Old Town'
column19: 'New Town' remained. The name Flagstaff was reinstated in 1884 when a post office was introduced alongside the railroad depot.The city has different names in local Native languages. In Diné Bizaad
column20: it is known as Kinłání Dookʼoʼoosłííd Biyaagi. This name is formed from Kinłání
column23: the name for the San Francisco Peaks but literally "the summit which never melts"
column25: indicating 'below' (see translations of "below; in a place beneath" on wiktionary): the city below the San Francisco Peaks. The word Kinłání alone may refer to Flagstaff
column26: but also can refer to Durango
column28: Flagstaff is known as Wii Hagnbaj. This is also a name for the San Francisco Peaks

column2: the county seat of Coconino County
column3: Arizona
column4: is located at 35°11′57″N 111°37′52″W. According to the United States Census Bureau
column5: the city has a total area of 63.9 square miles (165.5 km2)
column6: of which only 0.03 square miles (0.08 km2) (0.08%) is water. Flagstaff lies at approximately 7
column7: 000 feet (2
column8: 130 m) elevation
column9: and is surrounded by the largest contiguous ponderosa pine forest in North America. It is in a mountainous area
column10: and lies along the Rio de Flag watercourse. It is about 130 miles (210 km) north of the State capital
column11: Phoenix.The geology of the area is in line with that of the Colorado Plateau on which it lies
column12: with the Moenkopi red sandstone abundant in the city also used to build many of the distinctive buildings forming its cityscape. The cityscape of Flagstaff is its historic downtown area centered on Heritage Square
column13: with the historic nature of its restored buildings and local theme iconic to the city and representative of its culture. Flagstaff is one of the United States' sunniest and snowiest cities
column14: with a variable "semi-arid" climate and a monsoon season in summer.The San Francisco Peaks are a main aspect of Flagstaff's local geography and can be seen from everywhere in the city. Humphreys Peak is the highest point in Arizona at 12
column15: 633 feet (3
column16: 851 m); from trails up this mountain
column17: the entire State can be seen on a clear day. Several trails around the peaks provide views of the Grand Canyon. While the most popular access point is Arizona Snowbowl (southwest face)
column18: the peaks can also be approached from the north and east. The peaks are about 10 miles (16 km) northwest of downtown Flagstaff
column19: with the Snowbowl resort just southwest of Humphreys Peak. The wildlife of the peaks include mule deer

column1: Flagstaff lies on the southern edge of the Colorado Plateau
column2: and is largely limestone under San Francisco volcanic field. The oldest rock types of the area are part of North America's original crust
column3: Precambrian granite and schist from 1.7 to 1.8 billion years ago. On top of this is Paleozoic sandstone
column4: limestone
column5: shale and siltstone deposited on what was then (544 to 248 million years ago) different surfaces
column6: including a shallow seabed
column7: muddy land
column8: and sandy desert. The rock layers from this period are (bottom to top): Tapeats Sandstone
column9: Bright Angel Shale and Muav Limestone
column10: Martin Formation
column11: Redwall Limestone
column12: Supai Group
column13: Coconino Sandstone
column14: Toroweap Formation
column15: and Kaibab Limestone. The last three of these are still exposed. On top of the Paleozoic rock is Mesozoic Moenkopi Formation
column16: from 248 to 65 million years ago. Other Mesozoic layers formed on top of this
column17: but were eroded away. In the Flagstaff area
column18: layers of rock from the Paleozoic and Mesozoic eras accumulated up to 10
column21: but most of this was eroded. A soft basalt layer covers some of the rock at the surface.Moenkopi Formation red sandstone is a distinctive feature of Flagstaff
column22: as it was used as a building material from the 1880s because of its fire retardant properties. The source used for quarrying most of this rock was a deposit 1 mile east of the town
column23: which fell under the control of Charles Begg in 1887
column24: who then began selling the stone across the southwest – after he made a successful sale in California that expanded the business
column25: he was replaced in 1888 by a master quarryman. While it was used as building material across the West
column26: some of Flagstaff's most prominent buildings are famous for the stone
column32: including Old Main.In the Laramide orogeny
column33: which began about 65–75 million years ago
column34: the Western United States underwent stress in rock formation; in the Four Corners region this pushed up the preexisting layers and ultimately formed the Colorado Plateau (and the Rocky Mountains). Around Flagstaff more specifically
column35: this process deformed flat rock layers into folds
column36: and allowed surface rivers to cut deep canyons in the younger rock layers. From about 25 million years ago
column37: more faults were broken again in Flagstaff
column38: and volcanic activity began about 6 million years ago with magma flowing up these faults to create lava flows. Eruptions occurred between 3 million and 1
column40: affecting the Paleozoic and Mesozoic rocks. The city's Mount Elden is a lava dome made of dacite
column41: Sunset Crater is the youngest feature of the San Francisco volcanic field and formed in the last 1
column43: while S P Crater was formed between 75
column45: 000 years ago by piles of lapilli and volcanic bombs spouting from a lava lake.In the 1960s
column46: the geology and topography of the Flagstaff area
column48: was seen as similar to environments that would be encountered on the Moon in terms of planetary geology. The Astrogeology Research Program was therefore moved to Flagstaff in 1962

column1: Flagstaff's climate type on the Köppen climate classification system is variously reported as a warm dry-summer Mediterranean climate (Csb)
column2: a Hemiboreal climate (Dsb and Dfb)
column3: and a cold semi-arid climate (BSk). It is consistently described as "semi-arid". Flagstaff's Köppen type is recorded as Dsb in the city center
column4: with areas of BSk
column5: Csb
column6: Csa (hot-summer Mediterranean)
column7: Cwa (humid subtropical)
column8: and Dsa (humid hot summer) on the outskirts and bordering the city; it is mostly Dsb
column9: BSk
column10: and Csb.Northern Arizona experiences a summer monsoon season from July to September
column11: with Flagstaff's wettest months being July and August
column12: and its driest being June
column13: all in the summer; Mediterranean climates have wet season only in the winter. Mediterranean climate categorization does not consider snowfall.  Semi-arid climates will receive 10–20 inches (250–510 mm) of annual rainfall
column14: while Flagstaff experiences more.

column2: with some areas 5b
column3: meaning plants withstand temperatures down to −15 °F (−26 °C). It is in the Transition life zone; the concept of life zones was first observed in the Flagstaff area. Wind in Flagstaff typically blows southwesterly throughout the year
column4: based on topographical features. The city's climate data is observed from Flagstaff Pulliam Airport.The city receives precipitation every year
column5: with two distinct wet periods in the summer and winter; the summer monsoon season accounts for 34% of annual rainfall
column6: with the winter producing 28%. The summer monsoon season
column7: originating from the Mexican monsoon period
column8: is also wetter than winter
column9: with an average 7 inches (180 mm) compared to the winter's 6 inches (150 mm). Before the summer monsoon each year there is a dry period in May and June. Long-term average precipitation is 21.6 inches (550 mm) annually
column10: with much heavier rainfall attributed to El Niño events. Comparatively
column11: La Niña events have caused below-average rainfall.Since 1996 the city has been experiencing its driest period
column12: known as the Early-21st Century Drought. Richard Hereford of USGS speculates that the effects of the drought
column13: predicted to last until the late 2020s
column14: may be severe because of Flagstaff's growing population and global warming. The summer wet season is more reliable and consistent than other times of year
column15: but due to the high temperatures of the area this rainfall is quickly lost to evaporation. During the Early-21st Century Drought
column16: rainfall has been consistently below average in all but the summer season
column17: with temperature averages for all but the summer (which has remained consistent) also increasing.Equally
column18: snowfall has been lower during the extended dry period
column19: though the city set a new record for its highest daily snowfall on February 21
column21: with 35.9 inches (910 mm) and was still ranked as the United States' third-snowiest city in 2020 (based on 2018–19 National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration data). Flagstaff has consistently been among the snowiest cities in the United States
column22: and snow and winter culture is argued by Michael Weeks to be a large part of Flagstaff's identity. The Arizona Snowbowl is a major attraction
column23: though has had to make artificial snow during warmer seasons
column24: and the city tried to launch a bid to be the host city of the 1960 Winter Olympics. The maximum daily snow cover was 83 inches (210 cm) on December 20
column26: although the mean maximum for a full winter is only 20 inches (510 mm). However
column27: due to the infrequent and scattered nature of the snowstorms
column28: persistent snowpack into spring is rare. One notable exception occurred during the severe winter of 1915–16
column29: when successive Pacific storms buried the city under over 70 inches (178 cm) of snow
column30: and some residents were snowbound in their homes for several days.Though one of the least-sunny cities in Arizona
column31: Flagstaff still ranks among the United States' sunniest cities
column32: having sunshine for an average 78% of the year. The city receives much more sunshine than other snowy cities
column33: which are primarily in the north of the country.

column1: There are four seasons in Flagstaff
column2: with cool winter temperatures averaging 45 °F (7 °C) and warm summer temperatures averaging 80 °F (27 °C)
column3: pleasant compared to the rest of Arizona; the average annual snowfall is 97 inches (250 cm). Spring begins in April with pleasant weather. Sometimes
column4: snow reappears in May (and is not unheard of in June)
column5: but the spring period is typically mild and dry
column6: lasting until early June. The summer is measured between days when freezing temperatures occur
column7: beginning in June – the last freezing temperature generally in early June – and ending in September. Flagstaff's summer will receive a few days of daytime temperatures above 90 °F (32 °C)
column8: with cooler nighttime temperatures typically in the region of 40 °F (4 °C). Flagstaff's summers are also notable for the monsoon season in July and August
column9: when thunderstorms occur almost daily. Thunderstorm activity happens mostly during the daytime.Freezing temperatures (below 32 °F (0 °C)) return towards the end of September
column10: with the mild fall season having daytime temperatures around 60 °F (16 °C). With its many trees
column11: leaves do change color in Flagstaff's fall
column12: with the change starting at the end of September and happening throughout October. Fall lasts only until the snow comes in November
column13: with winter marked between periods of snowfall
column14: typically from November until mid-April at the latest. Temperatures in winter are usually below freezing
column15: going no higher than around 40 °F (4 °C) in the day
column16: even in sunshine. A combination of snow cover and high pressure occurring during winter months will cause the temperature to drop further
column17: once reaching a record low of −30 °F (−34 °C). Flagstaff's winter wet season is caused by Pacific storms and lasts from November through April.

column1: Flagstaff is an area "of great ecological variation" due to its diverse habitat life zones. Tree species abound the area
column2: which covers three arboreal life zones: Douglas fir and aspen forest
column3: Ponderosa pine forest
column4: and Pinyon-juniper woodland. It is at the heart of the Coconino National Forest. Within the Transition zone of the forest
column5: including in the city
column6: there are huge stands of ponderosa pine. Other species scattered among this region include Gambel oak
column7: quaking aspen
column8: and Rocky Mountain juniper trees.The Coconino National Forest and Flagstaff are within the largest contiguous ponderosa pine forest in North America. Here
column9: this tree type is formed as a climax forest
column10: with groups of trees containing different ages spread among the forest. Some of the groups are only a few trees
column11: some are acres large; other groups are even-aged. The irregularity of the tree groups leaves natural openings in the forest
column12: allowing for other plants to thrive. A grass cover of Arizona fescue grows around the area and shrub exists
column13: but there are few other tree species. As well as the Gambel oak
column14: quaking aspen
column15: and juniper trees
column16: pinyons can be found among the pines. Some of the open forest space contains bunchgrass
column17: and local animal species that roam on this include elk
column20: and Abert's squirrel.The arboretum in Flagstaff has an extensive regional collection of the Penstemon genus and hosts an annual Penstemon Festival.Coconino is also home to a variety of bird species
column21: which is further diversified by species from desert climates south of the Mogollon Rim still mixing in the area. The nearby lakes also attract wildlife. Birds that live around or visit Flagstaff include the thick-billed kingbird
column22: only documented in the area since 2016
column25: and waterfowl including the Eurasian wigeon and American wigeon.

column2: and exists in distinct areas. Downtown Flagstaff is a "narrow and slender" area between the NAU campus at its south and the Museum of Northern Arizona at the north. Flagstaff is a smaller city
column3: so its downtown is largely local and independent. The city's mall is found in East Flagstaff
column4: as is a Harkins movie theater and a country club and golf course. Residential properties in East Flagstaff are larger and more rural than other parts of the city. North West Flagstaff is directly north of downtown
column5: and is where the Snowbowl and Museum of Northern Arizona are found. West Flagstaff encompasses the area south and west of downtown
column6: including NAU and the Lake Mary neighborhood. It also covers the airport and Fort Tuthill (county park and the Pepsi Amphitheater)
column7: being bordered to the south by the urban areas of Kachina Village and Mountainaire. Outside of the city proper
column8: these urban areas have a "mountain-town feel". Flagstaff has an "urban forest park"
column9: Buffalo Park
column10: which sits on top of McMillan Mesa and used to be home to a zoo in the 1960s. Buffalo Park/McMillan Mesa bisects the city
column11: separating East Flagstaff from the West and Downtown.

column1: Flagstaff has two police departments: Flagstaff PD and NAU PD. NAU PD employs 30 officers and 25 students
column2: and is responsible for law enforcement on the campus. Flagstaff PD will share information of concern about the neighborhoods surrounding the NAU campus to the NAU PD
column3: and NAU PD may also respond to situations off-campus that involve students; NAU PD also investigates the missing person reports of students who are registered as resident on campus. From campus phones
column4: all 911 calls will go to NAU PD.The rate of crime in Flagstaff is above average
column5: while its violent crime is below average
column6: for the United States. For 2017
column7: the FBI's Uniform Crime Report indicated for Flagstaff a rate of 290 cases of violent crime per 100
column8: 000 people and 2
column9: 710 cases of property crime per 100
column10: 000 population; the violent crime rate across the US was 382.9 per 100
column12: Flagstaff had a rate of 469.44 cases of all crimes per 100
column13: 000 people
column14: up 10.69% on the total in 2017; this was below the average for Arizona
column15: but above the average for the US. Until 2017
column16: Flagstaff's crime rate was typically in line with the US average.The safest neighborhood in Flagstaff is Elden Pueblo
column17: with several downtown areas
column20: and Cosnino all in the top ten. In 2017
column21: Flagstaff PD responded to four hostage situations
column23: and fifteen explosive device removal calls. There were 3
column24: 262 criminal investigations. The Flagstaff narcotics task force headed up 'Operation Nightfall' between 2015 and 2017
column25: aiming to prevent the use of I-40 through the city being used by Mexican drug cartels for trafficking
column26: successfully seizing over 138 kg of cocaine. Within Flagstaff
column27: there were over 100 arrests relating to other narcotics crimes.NAU operates as a weapon-free and drug-free campus (even medical marijuana)
column28: with restrictions on alcohol possession for resident students over 21 within certain private areas of certain residence halls. In 2016
column29: it became a tobacco-free campus. Additionally
column30: alcohol may not be consumed in public on the campus. The overwhelming majority of NAU PD recorded crimes are related to drugs and alcohol
column31: with hundreds of arrests each year and over 1500 disciplinary referrals in 2018. The second-most recorded area of crime on the campus is gender based violence (rape
column33: with a few dozen cases. There are over 160 blue light phones on the campus; each has a large button that connects directly to NAU PD and provides the location of the call to them.The police in Flagstaff also deal with skunk-related problems
column34: including suspected burglaries that turn out to be skunks. The skunks can be an issue in the city
column35: as they start rabies epidemics among animals every few years.

column2: the city's economic base comprised the lumber
column3: railroad
column4: and ranching industries. Today
column5: that has largely been replaced by tourism
column6: education
column7: government
column8: and transportation. Some of the larger employers in Flagstaff are Northern Arizona University
column9: the Flagstaff Medical Center
column10: and the Flagstaff Unified School District. Tourism is a large contributor to the economy

column15: a 4.3-meter telescope with an instrument cube that can hold five instruments at once. Lowell Observatory and NOFS also are collaborators on the Navy Precision Optical Interferometer
column16: on nearby Anderson Mesa. NOFS is heavily involved with the science of star catalogs and astrometry
column17: or the positions and distances of stars and celestial objects.There are five industrial parks in the city

column21: a biotechnology research lab and manufacturer; SCA Tissue

column1: Flagstaff has a thriving tourism industry
column2: and has since the early 1900s
column3: primarily stemming from its proximity to the Grand Canyon National Park and other natural wonders
column4: giving it the nickname 'City of Seven Wonders'. Other natural wonders and native ruins
column5: Route 66
column6: and its astronomical history also bring tourism from out of state
column7: while people from further south in Arizona visit Flagstaff because of its cooler climate in the summer and its ski resort in the winter. The city has several hotels and restaurants
column8: including its historic hotels. The first hotel of the Ramada Inn chain opened in 1954 at the intersection of Routes 66
column10: and 89A
column11: adjacent to what was then Arizona State College (now NAU). The original building is still intact
column12: operating as a Super 8 motel. Flagstaff is said to attract a lot of the tourism for the entire county as it is the only large population center that can cater to tourists
column13: as well as being the location of information points for the National Park Service (NPS). In 1996
column14: 39% of Coconino County residents were employed in tourism. There are large service sectors
column15: particularly hotels and restaurants
column16: in Flagstaff
column17: with many of these companies having a close connection to NAU's School of Hotel and Restaurant Management
column18: to employ these students.Tourism to Flagstaff is a well-established industry
column19: but still relies on environmental forces. Nature and weather conditions can damage tourism; having a mild but warm summer temperature attracts tourists from many locales
column20: but storms and forest fires in its climate can be a detraction. Flagstaff also experiences very cold winters
column21: and despite a successful ski resort still sees less tourism in this period; decreasing snow levels also threaten the winter industry. The pristine condition of the natural sites can also experience degradation due to overuse through tourism
column22: losing its main selling point. The development of Tusayan into the Grand Canyon gateway town also affected Flagstaff's capture of some overnight tourists.

column2: a Wonder of the World
column3: is about 80 miles (130 km) northwest of Flagstaff. The first stagecoach tours to the Grand Canyon from the city began running from the Bank Hotel in 1892. In 2000
column4: about 5 million people visiting the Grand Canyon also visited Flagstaff. As Rick Heffernon wrote
column5: "the world recognizes only one Grand Canyon
column6: and northern Arizona has it". However
column7: he also suggested this can act to the area's detriment
column8: as the Grand Canyon is a world-class marvel and competes with other attractions of the same prestige for visitors
column9: which are all equally impressive; Flagstaff itself also competes with its nearby towns for access to the Grand Canyon
column10: several of which have growing themes based on it (like Tusayan and the Grand Canyon Village).Lowell Observatory celebrated its 125th anniversary in 2019 and continues to be a leading astronomical research center
column11: as well as a popular destination for visitors. More than 100
column12: 000 people visited in both 2018 and 2019; in 2019 the observatory opened its new Giovale Open Deck Observatory
column13: an observation plaza with a suite of six advanced telescopes.Arizona Snowbowl does not publish their revenue or make it public knowledge
column14: which makes it hard to calculate its impact on the Flagstaff economy. The Snowbowl supports approximately 200 full-time jobs and $12.08 million in economic output for the city of Flagstaff.Heffernon suggested that the perception of tourism from the residents of Flagstaff could affect the industry
column15: something researched in 1990 by NAU's Tim Schroeder. Schroeder saw six main areas of concern from Flagstaff residents: "Standard of Living for Residents; Future Use of Parks; Quality of Fire Protection; Occurrences of Crime; Changes in Community Values
column16: Norms and Customs; and Population Density". He acknowledged that the focus on fire protection was anomalous
column17: and likely caused by a particularly high concern surrounding recent wildfires at the time the survey had been conducted. The respondents to Schroeder's survey generally found that their "Opportunity for Jobs
column23: and Overall Quality of Life" had improved because of tourism to the area
column24: but that standards in terms of "Traffic and Road Conditions
column25: General Prices for Goods and Services
column30: and Occurrences of Crime" had worsened.

column1: Flagstaff has its own New Year's Eve tradition; in the city
column2: people gather around the Weatherford Hotel as a 70-pound (32 kg)
column3: 6-foot (1.8 m) tall
column4: metallic pine cone is dropped from the roof at midnight. The tradition originated in 1999
column5: when Henry Taylor and Sam Green (owners of the hotel)
column6: decorated a garbage can with paint
column7: lights
column8: and pine cones
column9: and dropped it from the roof of their building to mark the new millennium. By 2003 the event had become tradition
column10: and the current metallic pine cone was designed and built by Frank Mayorga of Mayorga Welding in the city.Local museums include the Museum of Northern Arizona
column11: which features displays of the biology
column12: archeology
column13: photography
column14: anthropology
column15: and native art of the Colorado Plateau
column16: and the Arboretum at Flagstaff
column17: a 200-acre (81 ha) arboretum containing 2
column18: 500 species of drought-tolerant native plants representative of the high desert region.A lot of the local culture is also focused on Route 66
column19: which originally ran between Chicago and Los Angeles
column20: greatly increased the accessibility to the area
column21: and enhanced the culture and tourism in Flagstaff. Route 66 remains a historic route
column22: passing through the city between Barstow
column26: the city hosts an annual event
column28: to highlight its connection to the famous highway.

column1: Flagstaff takes one of its nicknames from its legislative designation as the world's first International Dark Sky City
column2: a deliberate dark sky preserve area with measures to reduce light pollution. This was one of the world's first coordinated legislative efforts to do so. In the city there has been over fifty years of planning and development
column3: with the support of the ecologically-aware population and community advocates
column4: frequent government support
column5: and the assistance of major observatories in the area – including the United States Naval Observatory Flagstaff Station and Lowell Observatory.The city's designation as an International Dark Sky City was on October 24
column7: by the International Dark-Sky Association
column8: after a proposal by the city's own Dark Sky Coalition to start the preserve program. It is seen as a world precedent in dark sky preservation. Before this
column9: it had been nicknamed the "Skylight City" in the 1890s
column10: the same decade that the Lowell Observatory opened. In 1958
column11: it passed Ordinance 400
column12: which outlawed using large or powerful searchlights within city limits. In the 1980s a series of measures were introduced for the city and Coconino County
column13: and the Dark Sky Coalition was founded in 1999 by Chris Luginbuhl and Lance Diskan. Luginbuhl is a former U.S. Naval astronomer
column14: and Diskan had originally moved to Flagstaff from Los Angeles so that his children could grow up able to see stars
column15: saying that "part of being human is looking up at the stars and being awestruck." It was reported in an award-winning article that even though greater restrictions on types of public lighting were introduced in 1989
column16: requiring them all to be low-emission
column17: some public buildings like gas stations hadn't updated by 2002
column18: after the Dark Sky designation.Flagstaff and the surrounding area is split into four zones
column19: each permitted different levels of light emissions. The highest restrictions are in south and west Flagstaff (near NAU and its observatory)
column22: and Lowell Observatories. Photographs detecting emissions taken in 2017 show that Flagstaff's light is 14 times less than another Western city of comparable size
column25: which Luginbuhl described as "even better than [they] might have expected".

column1: Flagstaff has an active cultural scene. The city is home to the Flagstaff Symphony Orchestra
column2: which plays concerts from September through April at Ardrey Auditorium on the NAU campus. The city also attracts folk and contemporary acoustic musicians
column3: and offers several annual music festivals during the summer months
column4: such as the Flagstaff Friends of Traditional Music Festival
column5: the Flagstaff Music Festival
column6: and Pickin' in the Pines
column7: a three-day bluegrass and acoustic music festival held at the Pine Mountain Amphitheater at Fort Tuthill Fairgrounds. Popular bands play throughout the year at the Orpheum Theater
column8: and free concerts are held during the summer months at Heritage Square.Beyond music
column9: Flagstaff has a popular theater scene
column10: featuring several groups. Northern Arizona University Department of Theatre is an active and successful theater program that produces quality productions for the community as well as the campus. The department has won many prestigious awards
column11: including multiple invitations to the Kennedy Center American College Theater Festival. NAU Theatre performs in two facilities: the Clifford E. White Theatre (named for long-time professor Clifford E. White) and the Studio Theatre. Both facilities are housed in the Fine and Performing Arts Building on campus. A local community theater company called Theatrikos was founded in 1972 in the basement of the Weatherford Hotel
column12: and today puts on six major productions per year. In 2002
column13: the company moved into a new venue now known as the Doris-Harper White Community Playhouse
column14: a downtown building which was built in 1923 as an Elks Lodge and later became the Flagstaff library. Since 1995
column15: the Flagstaff Light Opera Company has performed a variety of musical theater and light opera productions throughout the year at the Sinagua Middle School auditorium. There are several dance companies in Flagstaff
column16: including Coconino Community College Dance Program
column17: Northern Arizona Preparatory Company and Canyon Movement
column18: which present periodic concerts and collaborate with the Flagstaff Symphony for free concerts during the summer and holiday seasons.A variety of weekend festivals occur throughout the year. The annual Northern Arizona Book Festival
column20: brings together authors to read and display their works. The Flagstaff Mountain Film Festival is held every October
column21: and features a variety of independent films and documentaries focusing on extreme sports
column23: and global topics. The festival is four days long and consists of several sessions of films.  The screenings are held at the Orpheum Theater in the historic downtown area. The summer months feature several festivals
column24: including Hopi and Navajo Festivals of Arts and Crafts
column27: and the Made in the Shade Beer Tasting Festival. For more than 20 years Flagstaff has hosted the 10-day Flagstaff Festival of Science in September.  It is a family event which features open houses
column30: and hands-on activities at area museums
column33: and the university. In-school programs also are an important part of the festival.  The festival begins with the annual Eugene Shoemaker keynote address. Guest speakers have included famous astronauts
column36: and scientists from many disciplines. The Coconino County Fair is held every September at the Fort Tuthill County Fairgrounds

column1: Flagstaff has no professional sports of its own
column2: but is home to the successful college sports teams of NAU. It is a popular training destination for a variety of elite sports
column3: largely due to its altitude and climate.

column1: Northern Arizona University sponsors 15 sports at the NCAA Division I level
column2: including a football team that competes at the Division I Football Championship Subdivision level. The NAU football team has a rivalry with the Southern Utah Thunderbirds
column3: known as the Grand Canyon Rivalry
column4: based on the universities residing on opposite sides of the Grand Canyon. All sports are members of the Big Sky Conference with the exception of the Women's Swimming & Diving team
column5: which competes in the Western Athletic Conference. The Men's Cross Country team has featured four straight top ten finishes at the NCAA Division I Cross Country championships. The track and field team has been home to several All-Americans
column6: including NCAA Champion and Olympian Lopez Lomong (and brother Peter Lomong)
column7: two-time NCAA Champion David McNeill
column8: and 2012 Olympian Diego Estrada.

column1: There are no major-league professional sports teams based in Flagstaff. However
column2: from 1988 to 2012 (with the exception of the 2005 season)
column3: the Arizona Cardinals of the National Football League held their summer training camp at Northern Arizona University. The 2005 training camp relocated to Prescott because of a norovirus outbreak at the university that emerged from a summer wrestling training camp and infected over 100 people. The NAU training camp was named as one of the top five training camps in the NFL by Sports Illustrated
column4: citing the cooler temperature
column5: scenic area
column6: and the possibility for fans to get close to athletes as key points. Players have said that the altitude of Flagstaff was the key benefit
column7: as well as seeing the dedication of fans traveling to the city
column8: but that they did not enjoy living in the NAU dorm rooms.The Cardinals left Flagstaff in summer 2013
column9: placing NAU at fault after the team was put in the visitors' facilities
column10: though NAU had offered the home facilities when the concern was raised
column11: and moved their training camp to the University of Phoenix's State Farm Stadium in Glendale. At Glendale
column12: they train in a domed stadium rather than outside
column13: which player Bertrand Berry said took away some of the feeling of training camp
column14: saying "there really isn't that need to practice outside when most of the games are inside
column15: but when you talk about building a team and going through adverse situations and bonding together
column16: I think they miss out on a little bit of that". The Cardinals had trained at NAU since the franchise moved to Arizona
column17: with Fox Sports reporting that "some argued they pulled the plug on the team's only Arizona tradition". Bill Bidwill
column19: was inducted into the Flagstaff Sports Foundation's Hall of Fame in 2009
column20: after bringing the team and resultant tourism boost to the city for over 20 years.

column1: Flagstaff is also a popular destination for altitude training. The first elite athletes to start altitude training in the city were those going to the 1968 Summer Olympics in Mexico City. A 2009 analysis showed that groups of 35 athletes spent three to eight weeks training in Flagstaff
column2: to positive effect. This was one of the highest number of athletes and longest periods among seventeen sites used in the research. Australian rules football team Collingwood Magpies regularly train at NAU facilities
column3: as does the Olympic-medal-winning Team GB British Swimming team. Another British Olympian
column4: Mo Farah
column5: trains in Flagstaff.Long-distance runner Andrea Seccafien used to altitude train in Flagstaff but moved to Australia in 2018
column6: saying "We don't go to Flagstaff or St. Moritz anymore which are more populated by runners and the general public. [...] Flagstaff feels quite metropolitan compared to where we are now"; the Canadian Running Magazine noted that the city becomes host to many professional runners in the spring. The popularity among runners is because of the altitude and pleasant climate
column7: making it "for distance runners [...] a practically unparalleled paradise"
column8: known as the "running mecca". Runner Nick Hilton said that "Flagstaff and Boulder
column9: Colorado
column10: are probably the two biggest centers for elite distance runners in the country".The HYPO2 altitude training center in the city is used by swimmers and runners alike
column11: and is an elite facility that attracts many teams from around the world. HYPO2 was created in 2012
column12: largely with staff from NAU's Center for High Altitude Training
column13: which closed in 2009. As of 2019
column14: over 85 Olympic medalists from 44 countries trained at the facility. In 2016
column15: the city advertised NAU and the HYPO2 with promotions saying "The Road to Rio Runs Through Flagstaff"
column16: prominently noting that if Flagstaff (with its training athletes) was a country
column17: it would be in the top 10 of Olympic-medal winning nations since 1996.

column1: Flagstaff has acquired a reputation as a magnet for outdoor enthusiasts

column3: high elevation
column4: and amenable weather attract campers
column5: backpackers
column6: climbers
column7: recreation and elite runners

column10: next to city hall

column13: or "FUTS" includes more than 50 miles of paved and unpaved trails for hiking

column17: and annual cross country ski races. Several major river running operators are headquartered in Flagstaff

column1: Flagstaff is the county seat of Coconino County.
The city government is organized under a council-manager form of government. The mayor of Flagstaff is Coral Evans
column2: who was elected in November 2016
column3: and the town council consists of the mayor and six councilmembers: Adam Shimoni (vice mayor)
column4: Regina Salas
column5: Jim McCarthy
column6: Jamie Whelan
column7: Charlie Odegaard
column8: and Austin Aslan. On July 2
column10: the city council named Greg Clifton as city manager among 50 candidates. Regular meetings of the city council are held on the first and third Tuesday of every month.At the state level
column11: Flagstaff is in the 6th legislative district. In the Arizona State Senate
column12: the 6th is represented by Sylvia Allen (R) of Snowflake. In the House of Representatives
column13: the 6th is represented by Bob Thorpe (R) of Flagstaff and Walter Blackman (R) of Snowflake.

column2: Flagstaff is within Arizona's 1st congressional district
column3: which is the tenth largest congressional district
column4: covering nearly 60
column5: 000 sq. miles. The district is represented by Tom O'Halleran (D) of Sedona.

column1: The City of Flagstaff raised its minimum wage above the State minimum wage in 2017. This wage increase was the result of a ballot measure – Proposition 414 – on the November 8
column3: ballot.  The City Council of Flagstaff then passed Title 15 of the City Ordinance
column4: which provided for implementation of the new law.  The new minimum wage in Flagstaff on July 1
column7: fifty cents more than the Arizona state minimum wage.  On January 1
column9: the minimum wage rose to $13.00.

column2: with 11
column3: 500 students and 800 faculty and staff
column4: in the Flagstaff Unified School District. In 1997
column5: Mount Elden Middle School was named an A+ School
column6: citing an outstanding school climate
column7: progressive use of technology and zero-tolerance approach to discipline. The 1999 National Science Teacher of the Year
column8: David Thompson
column9: teaches physics at Coconino High School. Three Arizona Teachers of the Year from 2001 through 2003 teach at Flagstaff High School. In 2012
column10: Flagstaff was named named America’s first STEM Community. In addition to the numerous public schools

column12: Northland Preparatory Academy (ranked No. 52 in US News's America's Top 100 Best High Schools)
column13: the Flagstaff Arts and Leadership Academy

column15: BASIS Flagstaff (ranked No. 2 in The Washington Post's America's Most Challenging High schools) and the Montessori Schools of Flagstaff.

column1: Flagstaff is home to three institutions of higher education
column2: Northern Arizona University (one of the three public state universities in Arizona); Coconino Community College; and Flagstaff College (a very small upper-division college with only one major--sustainability and social justice).

column1: The city is connected to Phoenix by Interstate 17 (I-17)
column2: and to Los Angeles
column3: Las Vegas (via Route 93)
column4: Page
column5: and Albuquerque by Interstate 40 (I-40). Page can also be reached on Route 89 from the city
column6: as can Salt Lake City and
column7: ultimately
column8: Canada. The main road through Flagstaff is Route 66/Santa Fe Avenue
column9: which runs parallel to the Burlington Northern Santa Fe (BNSF) Railway line east–west through the city. Downtown Flagstaff and the surrounding neighborhoods are separated from East Flagstaff by Buffalo Park
column10: with the city connected by Route 66 and I-40. Route 66 is connected to the interstates in downtown by Milton Road
column11: running roughly south alongside the NAU campus; Milton Road then merges into I-17. Flagstaff is connected to Sedona and Prescott by State Route 89A
column12: which Beulah Boulevard merges into
column13: and to the Grand Canyon by Route 180
column14: which Fort Valley Road merges into just northwest of the city. It is the northern terminus of I-17 and Route 89A
column15: and the southern terminus of Route 89.Several towns are close to Flagstaff along I-40 and I-17. Approximately 6 miles (9.7 km) south are the small urban areas of Kachina Village (west of I-17) and Mountainaire (east of I-17; 2 miles (3.2 km)). About 35 miles (56 km) to the west is Williams
column16: 20 miles (32 km) to the south is Munds Park
column17: and 30 miles (48 km) to the south on Route 89A is Sedona. 15 miles (24 km) to the east of Flagstaff is the town of Winona.From the city
column18: Amtrak provides connecting Thruway Motorcoach service via Open Road Tours
column19: which has an office inside the rail depot. Local bus service is provided throughout the city by the Mountain Line. Interstate bus service is provided by Greyhound Lines and Flixbus. Groome Transportation provides in-state shuttle service. Bus service to the Hopi Reservation is provided by Hopi Senom Transit
column20: and to Tuba City and the Navajo Nation by Navajo Transit.

column1: The major rail corridor running through Flagstaff is the Southern Transcon
column2: originally built by the Santa Fe Railroad and now owned and operated by the BNSF Railway. Passenger rail service is provided by Amtrak at the downtown Flagstaff station
column3: connecting on east–west routes to Los Angeles and Albuquerque via the Southwest Chief line.

column1: Air travel is available through Flagstaff Pulliam Airport (IATA: FLG
column2: ICAO: KFLG
column3: FAA LID: FLG)
column4: just south of the city. The airport is primarily a small
column5: general aviation airport with a single 6
column6: 999-foot (2
column7: 133 m) runway. The airport finished a major expansion project to add 1
column8: 800 feet (550 m) to the north end of the runway and lengthen the taxiway in 2007. The primary purpose of the project was to increase its viability for commercial and regional jets. Service to connecting flights at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport is provided by American Airlines operated by Mesa Airlines. As of January 2020 the airport offers year-round direct flights to Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport
column9: Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport
column10: and Denver International Airport
column11: on American Airlines and United Airlines.

column1: Flagstaff is fairly bike-friendly; there are bike lanes on many major streets
column2: and the Flagstaff Urban Trails System (FUTS) includes more than 50 miles of off-street trails that wind throughout the community. In 2006 Flagstaff was designated a Bicycle-Friendly Community by the League of American Bicyclists. About nine percent of trips in Flagstaff are made by bicycle.

column1: Electricity generation in Flagstaff is provided by Arizona Public Service
column2: an electric utility subsidiary operated by parent company Pinnacle West. The primary generating station near Flagstaff is the coal-fired
column3: 995-MW Cholla Power Plant
column4: near Holbrook
column5: which uses coal from the McKinley Mine in New Mexico. Near Page is the coal-fired
column6: 750-MW Navajo Power Plant
column7: supplied by an electric railroad that delivers coal from a mine on the Navajo and Hopi reservations in northern Arizona. Flagstaff is also home to Arizona's first commercial solar power generating station
column8: which was built in 1997 and provides 87 kW of electricity. Combined with 16 other solar power locations in Arizona
column9: the system provides over 5 MW of electricity statewide.Drinking water in Flagstaff is produced from conventional surface water treatment at the Lake Mary Water Treatment Plant
column10: on Upper Lake Mary
column11: as well as from springs at the inner basin of the San Francisco Peaks. Groundwater from several water wells throughout the city and surrounding area provide additional sources of drinking water. Water and wastewater services are provided by the City of Flagstaff.

column1: Natural gas is provided by UniSource Energy Services. CenturyLink QC is the incumbent local exchange carrier. Cable television service is offered by Suddenlink Communications.
The first hospital in the city was opened in 1936
column2: by Charles Sechrist. The city's primary hospital is the 267-bed Flagstaff Medical Center
column3: on the north side of downtown Flagstaff. The hospital was founded in 1936
column4: and serves as the major regional trauma center for northern Arizona.

column1: The major daily newspaper in Flagstaff is the Arizona Daily Sun. Northern Arizona University's weekly newspaper The Lumberjack also covers Flagstaff news
column2: while the other publications that serve the city include weeklies Flagstaff Live and the Navajo Hopi Observer
column3: and monthlies Mountain Living Magazine and The Noise. NAU runs several radio stations including KNAU and KPUB and their translator stations
column4: which provide NPR and PRI news coverage
column5: as well as classical music.Flagstaff is included in the Phoenix Designated market area (DMA)
column6: the 13th largest in the U.S. Over-the-air television service is provided mostly by low-powered repeaters of the Phoenix stations. There is one local broadcast television station serving the city
column7: KFPH-13 (TeleFutura). In reality television
column8: Extreme Makeover: Home Edition built a home just outside Flagstaff for slain soldier Lori Piestewa's two children and parents in 2005.  In December 2007
column9: talk show hostess Ellen DeGeneres selected Flagstaff as the winner of her show's "Wish You Were Here" contest.

column2: the city was considered as a site for the film The Squaw Man by Jesse Lasky and Cecil B. DeMille
column3: but was abandoned in favor of Hollywood. During the 1940s and 1950s
column4: over 100 Westerns were filmed in Sedona and Oak Creek Canyon. The Hotel Monte Vista in Flagstaff hosted many film stars during this era
column5: including Jane Russell
column6: Gary Cooper
column7: Spencer Tracy
column8: John Wayne
column9: and Bing Crosby. A scene from the movie Casablanca was filmed in one of the rooms of the hotel.Several films then used Flagstaff's Route 66 in scenes: the 1969 film Easy Rider were filmed on Milton Road and Route 66 as well as near Sunset Crater; a moment in the film National Lampoon's Vacation was filmed at a truck stop gas station near Little America Hotel in 1983; a small scene in Midnight Run was filmed in Flagstaff at the train depot
column10: and the city was referenced in the film; several of the running scenes in Forrest Gump were filmed in and around the area
column11: including a memorable scene in which Forrest is seen jogging in downtown Flagstaff and gives inspiration to a bumper sticker designer; parts of 2007 Academy Award winner Little Miss Sunshine were filmed at the junction of I-40 and I-17 in Flagstaff; and Terminal Velocity was partially filmed in the city. Grizzly Peak Films also filmed Sasquatch Mountain
column12: a feature-length film for the Science Fiction Channel about a Yeti
column13: in Flagstaff and Williams.

column1: Notable people born in or associated with Flagstaff include the politician Bruce Babbitt
column2: actor Ted Danson
column3: athlete Mike Shanahan
column4: and writer Diana Gabaldon.
